title: [FR] mlflow.artifacts.download_artifacts throws "cannot schedule new futures after interpreter shutdown" in Python 3.10
body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [X] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Willingness to contribute

No. I cannot contribute a bug fix at this time.

### MLflow version

- Client: 1.26.1


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: Debian Linux 11
- **Python version**: 3.10.8
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**:


### Describe the problem

I get the error described above when I try to execute **mlflow.artifacts.download_artifacts**. This happens both when I try to use proxied artifact access (described [here](https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#scenario-5-mlflow-tracking-server-enabled-with-proxied-artifact-storage-access)), and direct artifact access (described [here](https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#scenario-4-mlflow-with-remote-tracking-server-backend-and-artifact-stores)). In both cases, I'm able to upload artifacts with no problems (using **mlflow.log_artifact** and **mlflow.log_dict**). I get `RuntimeError: cannot schedule new futures after interpreter shutdown` (stacktrace below).

NOTE: The issue might be related to the one reported here: [link](https://github.com/boto/s3transfer/issues/197#issuecomment-1016026027) I am running **mlflow.artifacts.download_artifacts** in a daemon thread (callback for a message queue consumer), so adding `thread.join` to the calling thread isn't an option for me. If this is indeed the root cause, is there a way to configure the boto3 dependency by setting the `use_threads` property of the `TransferConfig` object to **False**? Or would I have to use boto3 client instead of the MLFlow client for multi-threaded downloads with Python 3.10?

### Tracking information

System information: Linux #21~20.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Wed Mar 16 11:54:08 UTC 2022
Python version: 3.10.8
MLflow version: 2.0.1
MLflow module location: /usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mlflow/__init__.py
Tracking URI: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
Registry URI: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
MLflow environment variables: {
    "MLFLOW_S3_ENDPOINT_URL": "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX",
    "MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI": "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX"
}
MLflow dependencies: {
    "click": "8.0.4",
    "cloudpickle": "2.2.0",
    "databricks-cli": "0.17.3",
    "entrypoints": "0.4",
    "gitpython": "3.1.29",
    "pyyaml": "5.4.1",
    "protobuf": "3.19.5",
    "pytz": "2022.6",
    "requests": "2.28.1",
    "packaging": "21.3",
    "importlib-metadata": "5.0.0",
    "sqlparse": "0.4.3",
    "alembic": "1.8.1",
    "docker": "6.0.1",
    "Flask": "2.2.2",
    "numpy": "1.23.5",
    "scipy": "1.9.3",
    "pandas": "1.5.1",
    "querystring-parser": "1.2.4",
    "sqlalchemy": "1.4.44",
    "scikit-learn": "1.1.3",
    "pyarrow": "10.0.1",
    "shap": "0.41.0",
    "markdown": "3.4.1",
    "matplotlib": "3.6.2",
    "gunicorn": "20.1.0",
    "Jinja2": "3.1.2"
}

### Code to reproduce issue

```
import mlflow
import logging

import mlflow
with mlflow.start_run() as run:
    artifact_uri = run.info.artifact_uri
    mlflow.log_dict({"test": "123"}, "config.json")
    path = mlflow.artifacts.download_artifacts(artifact_uri + "/config.json") 
    logging.info(path)
```

### Stack trace

```
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mlflow/artifacts/__init__.py", line 56, in download_artifacts
    return _download_artifact_from_uri(artifact_uri, output_path=dst_path)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/artifact_utils.py", line 100, in _download_artifact_from_uri
    return get_artifact_repository(artifact_uri=root_uri).download_artifacts(
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mlflow/store/artifact/artifact_repo.py", line 244, in download_artifacts
    inflight_downloads = async_download_artifact(
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mlflow/store/artifact/artifact_repo.py", line 155, in async_download_artifact
    download_future = self.thread_pool.submit(
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.10/concurrent/futures/thread.py", line 169, in submit
    raise RuntimeError('cannot schedule new futures after '
RuntimeError: cannot schedule new futures after interpreter shutdown
```

### Other info / logs

_No response_

### What component(s) does this bug affect?

- [ ] `area/artifacts`: Artifact stores and artifact logging
- [ ] `area/build`: Build and test infrastructure for MLflow
- [ ] `area/docs`: MLflow documentation pages
- [ ] `area/examples`: Example code
- [ ] `area/model-registry`: Model Registry service, APIs, and the fluent client calls for Model Registry
- [ ] `area/models`: MLmodel format, model serialization/deserialization, flavors
- [ ] `area/recipes`: Recipes, Recipe APIs, Recipe configs, Recipe Templates
- [ ] `area/projects`: MLproject format, project running backends
- [ ] `area/scoring`: MLflow Model server, model deployment tools, Spark UDFs
- [ ] `area/server-infra`: MLflow Tracking server backend
- [ ] `area/tracking`: Tracking Service, tracking client APIs, autologging

### What interface(s) does this bug affect?

- [ ] `area/uiux`: Front-end, user experience, plotting, JavaScript, JavaScript dev server
- [ ] `area/docker`: Docker use across MLflow's components, such as MLflow Projects and MLflow Models
- [ ] `area/sqlalchemy`: Use of SQLAlchemy in the Tracking Service or Model Registry
- [ ] `area/windows`: Windows support

### What language(s) does this bug affect?

- [ ] `language/r`: R APIs and clients
- [ ] `language/java`: Java APIs and clients
- [ ] `language/new`: Proposals for new client languages

### What integration(s) does this bug affect?

- [ ] `integrations/azure`: Azure and Azure ML integrations
- [ ] `integrations/sagemaker`: SageMaker integrations
- [ ] `integrations/databricks`: Databricks integrations
